It received its name from the historical province of [[Hida Province]], which was centered around the same area. The official ''[[kanji]]'' for the city is actually 飛驒, which uses the old rendering of the 騨 character. However, the 驒 characters is not included on the official list of usable characters (as decided by the [[Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications]]), so the 騨 character is often used outside of the city. ==History== The city was established on February 1, 2004 by the merger of the towns of ''Furukawa'' and ''Kamioka'' and the villages of ''Kawai'' and ''Miyagawa'', all from [[Yoshiki District, Gifu|Yoshiki District]]. ==Geography== The city is located on the northern part of the Hida Plateau. The city is geographically divided into two areas, the eastern and western half. The [[Takahara River]] flows through the eastern half the city and the Miya River flows through the western half (both rivers are part of the [[Jinzū River]] river system). A mountainous region separates the two sides and the population generally clusters around the two river valleys. Much of the area within the city's borders is covered in forests. There are many mountains that reach higher than {{Convert|1000|ft|0|on}}, though some peaks in the [[Hida Mountains]] reach even higher, going beyond {{Convert|2000|ft|0|on}}. ==Economy== The main two traditional economies in the city are the production of ''[[sake]]'' and [[Japanese candles]]. The Furukawa area of the city is known for both of these crafts, though the Kamioka section is also known for its ''sake'' production. ==Festival in Hida== Furukawa Festival, a famous for festival in Gifu Prefecture, with this event held on every April.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} ==Transportation== ===Railroad=== [[Central Japan Railway Company|JR Central]] operates seven stations within Hida along the [[Takayama Main Line]]. The main station for the city is [[Hida-Furukawa Station]]. The other six stations are north of Hida-Furukawa and are, in order: [[Sugisaki Station|Sugisaki]], [[Hida-Hosoe Station|Hida-Hosoe]], [[Tsunogawa Station|Tsunogawa]], [[Sakakami Station|Sakakami]], [[Utsubo Station|Utsubo]] and [[Sugihara Station|Sugihara]] stations. ===Highway=== The major expressway through the city is the [[Tōkai-Hokuriku Expressway]], which connects the cities of [[Nagoya]] and [[Gifu, Gifu|Gifu]] with [[Toyama, Toyama|Toyama]]. Four national highways run through the city as well: National Routes [[Japan National Route 41|41]], [[Japan National Route 360|360]], [[Japan National Route 471|471]] and [[Japan National Route 472|472]]. ==Neighboring municipalities== ;Gifu Prefecture :[[Takayama, Gifu|Takayama]], [[Shirakawa, Gifu (village)|Shirakawa]] ([[Ōno District, Gifu|Ōno District]]) ;Toyama Prefecture :[[Toyama, Toyama|Toyama]], [[Nanto, Toyama|Nanto]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category-inline}} *[http://www.city.hida.gifu.jp/ Official site] {{ja icon}} {{Gifu}} [[Category:Cities in Gifu Prefecture]]
